Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of Stable Isotope Instrumentation for Biogeochemistry Research and Teaching at the University of Cincinnati
Award.AbstractNarration:
MRI: Acquisition of Stable Isotope Instrumentation for Biogeochemistry Research and Teaching at the University of Cincinnati

Support from the National Science Foundation will allow for the purchase of a stable isotope ratio mass spectrometer (IRMS) and associated peripheral devices for the stable isotope analysis of plant biomarkers, bioapatite and calcite, organic matter, water, and atmospheric methane. The IRMS will enable faculty, post-doctoral researchers, and graduate and undergraduate students - both at the University of Cincinnati and regionally - to conduct research projects on a broad array of topics. These topics will include (1) characterizing modern carbon isotope fractionation patterns in plant terpenoids and n-alkyl lipids (biomarkers) to better develop paleoclimate and paleoecological applications, (2) using carbon and hydrogen isotopes of terrestrial plant biomarkers to examine Paleogene and Neogene paleoclimate and paleovegetation history, (3) assessing patterns in stable isotope values in mammal tissues to understand foraging ecology and species interactions, (4) reconstructing diet and habit for extinct mammals with implications for human-driven extinctions, (5) characterizing Permian-Early Triassic paleoenvironments in the global ocean and understanding the link to the contemporaneous marine biotic crisis, (6) investigating the biogeochemistry of Late Pennsylvanian paleoenvironments associated with extensive black shale deposits, (7) characterizing atmospheric methane emissions using carbon and hydrogen isotopes, (8) constraining impacts of shale gas extraction on methane emissions, (9) characterizing methane biogeochemistry in Arctic ecosystems, and many other studies planned by the PIs and other users at the University of Cincinnati and within the region.

Faculty, staff, and graduate students within the Departments of Geology, Anthropology, Geography, and Biology at the University of Cincinnati and from other regional institutions will use this state-of-the-art stable isotope ratio mass spectrometer to address a wide array of biogeochemical research questions. This instrumentation will take highly accurate measurements of the stable isotope ratios of carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, and oxygen, which will further the PIs research examining Earth system processes, including unraveling past changes in climate and ecology and tracking the various pathways of carbon, water, and nutrients through Earth?s systems. This will provide the tools necessary for the PIs to greatly improve and expand on current interdisciplinary research activities in biogeochemistry, spanning scales from biochemical to biospheric and from geologic to modern time scales. This will be critical for advancing research in the areas of (1) terrestrial carbon cycling, (2) community ecology and human impacts, (3) climate and plant paleoecology, (4) marine chemistry and paleoceanography, and (5) atmospheric methane dynamics in urban and Arctic ecosystems. The instrumentation will provide training and research opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students and will immediately benefit a new upper level undergraduate and graduate course on stable isotope ecology. Programs currently in place in the Department of Geology will use this instrumentation for training and research purposes including the Women in Science and Engineering (WISE) program, the Graduate-Undergraduate Mentoring Program, and the Capstone Experience, required for all undergraduate students. The department is actively participating in Earth science outreach programs for K-12 students at Cincinnati Public Schools (50% under-represented minority students). Results from research projects using this instrumentation will be disseminated through student and faculty presentations at national and international scientific meetings, publications in peer-reviewed journals, and online data repositories.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Support from the National Science Foundation was used to purchase a stable isotope ratio mass spectrometer (IRMS) and associated peripheral devices to develop a stable isotope program at the University of Cincinnati. This instrumentation, which provides highly accurate measurements of the stable isotope ratios of carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, and oxygen, furthered the PIs’ research examining Earth systems processes, including unraveling past changes in climate and ecology and tracking the various pathways of carbon, water, and nutrients through Earth’s systems. The IRMS has enabled faculty, post-doctoral researchers, and graduate and undergraduate students - both at the University of Cincinnati and regionally - to conduct research projects in a broad array of interdisciplinary research areas. The IRMS provided the tools necessary for the PIs to greatly improve and expand on their interdisciplinary research activities in biogeochemistry, spanning scales from biochemical to biospheric, and from geologic to modern. The instrumentation/facility was, and will continue to be, critical for advancing research in the areas of (1) terrestrial carbon cycling, (2) community and foraging ecology and paleoenvironmental reconstruction, (3) climate and plant paleoecology, (4) marine chemistry and paleoceanography, and (5) atmospheric and groundwater methane sources.

During the award period, we built a state of the art IRMS laboratory that has supported the research of the PIs as well as numerous graduate and undergraduate students, collaborative research projects with colleagues locally, regionally, and internationally, and class instruction and hands-on workshops. This award supported the PIs’ research over the past four years by providing instrumentation that was critical to their research programs. Three of these PIs were early career during this award process and this instrumentation was critical for development of their research programs at UC.

Over the past four years, the IRMS generated results that were used in 8 published papers, 1 paper in revision, 3 papers in review, and at least 10 manuscripts that are in preparation. In addition, 54 meeting abstracts were presented, with the majority (38) presented or co-authored by students. The PIs also trained and are continuing to train 9 Ph.D. students, 9 M.S. students, 3 M.A. students, and 14 undergraduate students undertaking independent research projects. Of these students, 23 were women and at least 2 were from underrepresented minorities.

PIs Diefendorf and Crowley have and will continue to use the IRMS to support undergraduate and graduate training as part of the courses they teach. For example, Diefendorf used the IRMS in his Geoscience Workshop – Techniques in Stable Isotopes, which was taught in 2015 and 2016. This provided students (a mix of graduate and undergraduate) hands-on experiences to analyze samples collected from a nearby lake to understand processes that result in isotopic fractionation. Diefendorf also used the IRMS lab for his Stable Isotope Geochemistry course for a hands-on activity as part of the course (taught in 2014 and 2016). Crowley uses the instrument in her Stable Isotope Ecology course through group led projects. In this course (taught in 2014 and 2016), undergraduate and graduate students from Geology, Anthropology, Biology, and Geography design and carry out research projects. To date, this course has given 37 students the opportunity to work in the IRMS facility. UC Assistant Professor Andy Czaja also used the IRMS for his Earth’s Early Biosphere course where students analyze 2+ billion year old rocks to detect signatures of life. In total, we have trained 115 students as part of these courses. This NSF-supported IRMS facility will continue to be a critical asset to the PIs and their research and teaching programs over the coming years.
